reviews.title: Great. Like staying at a friend's
reviews.text: My first stay at the Olivier was for Jazz Fest 2003. I recently stayed again for business. I think the Olivier is great. It is an old, historic French Quarter building in humid New Orleans and with that comes certain things. The hotel shows its age and the sheets may not match, but they're clean. When I stay at the Olivier I don't feel like I'm staying in a hotel, I feel like I'm staying at a friend's house in the Quarter. No, the Olivier isn't for everyone, but if you like places with character it's a great place to stay. Musicians agree and so does a certain actor from HBO's Sex and the City. Ask for rooms by the pool, or the Creole Cottage. The only down side about the Olivier House is that one must cross Bourbon St. to get there. I can't stand Bourbon St. Bourbon St. is not New Orleans.

reviews.title: Strange and Wonderful
reviews.text: The Olivier House is one of my favorite places to stay in NO. I spend 5 days there every year for Mardi Gras. Granted you'll have to put up with peeling wallpaper, old mattresses, leaky windows and falling plaster, but the hotel has some wierd charm that makes it all worth while. There are plenty sterile places to stay in the Quarter but something about walking on the same floors that were walked on 200 years ago appeals to me. Not for the anal-retentive traveler. Every stay is an adventure. You will be treated like family.

reviews.title: An Awful Hotel
reviews.text: This was the worst hotel I have ever stayed in. I will never stay there again or recommend it. The elevator was so small that a person and luggage would not fit. It had to be entered from an outside corridor in the rain. We had to take the stairway four floors. The first room was dirty (dust on furniture, floor and curtains). The bathroom looked as if it had not been cleaned. I am not sure the bed lines were fresh, they appeared to have been bought at a Goodwill store. The bed sagged so that it appeared like a hot dog bun. The entry door had a large crack. We were moved to an attic room that had a leaking lavatory (it puddled in the floor) in the bathroom, no shower curtain or door. The bed was only a little better than the first room. The couch was so dirty one did not want to sit on it. The AC could not be regulated so it was cold all weekend.

reviews.title: Always great
reviews.text: I have stayed at the Olivier House several times and have been more than pleased with the service and accomodations every time. It is a quaintly beautiful little hotel in the heart of the french quarter, oozing with charm. It is not the lap of luxury and it doesn't pretend to be. However, it does provide an old world elegance not found in boutique hotels that are twice the price. If you are looking for a uniquely wonderful New Orleans experience a stones throw from Bourbon Street look no further.

reviews.title: Great hotel
reviews.text: Have stayed at the Olivier House on several occasions and have loved it everytime. The hotel is vintage New Olreans. The rooms are very clean and the staff is very accomodating. If your wanting a five star hotel then go to the Hyatt. If you looking for a nice hotel located in the heart of the French Quarter, look no further, the Oliver House is for you.

reviews.title: Like staying in an abandoned house or homeless shelter
reviews.text: First I will say that OH is the worst place I have ever stayed. I had reservations at a well known hotel but decided, since my travel companions had never been to NO, that maybe something more funky would be better. I was wrong. My first clue as to how bad it was should have been when the cab driver who appeared to have issues with cleanliness commented on how nice OH was. We were escorted to a room with 2 four poster beds that were broken and the posts glued ot taped back on it was filthy, moldy and dark. I was also concerned about a strange mirror that looked like a two-way mirror used in interrogation rooms. The bathroom looked like it possibly had not been cleaned in months.The staff was nice but strange. I felt like I was trapped in an episode of Scooby Doo. We lasted the 2 nights and made the best of it but...I could have had better accomadations at the homeless shelter. It was so bad that we took pictures to show people back home how awful it was.

reviews.title: Funky - NOT THE Holiday Inn - anbd thank God for That!
reviews.text: definitely won't be back.

reviews.title: I loved this unique hotel
reviews.text: If your tastes are very white bread, then stay away - go to the Holiday Inn. But if you like a place a little off-beat & VERY New Orleans then the Olivier House is perfect.

reviews.title: charming place for the price
reviews.text: This slightly mouldering Grande Dame of a Creole Mansion is located right off Bourbon street in the heart of the Vieux Carre but far enough off to where it is pretty quiet in the courtyards.

reviews.title: Pretty low-rent...
reviews.text: Jim and Kathy the owners are friendly and very, well, accommodating. To the folks who had problems - I say SPEAK UP! I've stayed there many times since the late 80s and anytime there was a problem it was addressed as long as I told them what I wanted/needed and didn't expect them to read my mind.
We had a large group stay and had 7 different rooms. All the rooms were interesting and unique with nice public areas. Everyone found the place interesting.
reviews.title: Interesting French Quarter experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The only minor issue was we were in town during an unusually cool few nights and the central heating was uneven between the rooms. Rooms on the lower floors were cold and those on the upper floors got warm. The hotel mgmt. did their best to accomodate adding space heaters in a few rooms. Other rooms we ran the window A/C unit or opened the door to cool things off.
reviews.title: This hotel is one of my favorite haunts.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This delightful hotel is situated right off the corner of Bourbon Street on Toulouse in the French Quarter. If you enjoy historic charm, then look no further then the Olivier House. The Olivier House Hotel is one of a number of hotels that are named on the French Quarter Haunted List; apparently it is haunted by a spirit named Elizabeth but I have never seen any evidence of that. My son and I stayed here when we were building homes for Habitat during the Katrina Relief Effort and it continues to be one of my favorite stopovers.
reviews.title: Great stay in a charming hotel!

reviews.text: The original section of this mid eighteenth century Creole home is still intact; from the beautiful wool carpets that grace the huge hallway entrance and the adjoining parlor, to the ornate wall hangings and original light fixtures; it is no surprise that the Oliver House is most preferred among theater people. If you choose to bypass the eye catching wooden stairwell to take the elevator to get to your room, there is a hidden door under the arched staircase; you’ll have to duck to open it but it’s worth the short jaunt. The door will open onto to a beautiful court yard containing a miniature swimming pool that is surrounded by lush plants and trees. Take a short walk on the patio cobble stones in the opposite direction, turn left and ten feet away you’ll discover a minuscule elevator. If you suffer from claustrophobia I suggest you take the stairwell to your room; the elevator is approximately 4’ x 2’ and if you’re toting luggage it can be a real feat getting in and closing the door. The creaks and groans of the antique machinery may make one squeamish but I think it adds the ambiance of this popular hotel. The staff is very friendly and polite. I highly recommend that you reserve your room well in advance and specifically request a room that has a balcony facing Toulouse Street.
reviews.title: Old world charm, close to the action

reviews.text: We stayed in room 303 for four nights recently and were very happy. The room had a balcony overlooking the courtyard pool area, a nicely renovated bathroom and an ornate iron bed against the backdrop of an ancient looking brick wall. It was well furnished, clean, roomy and comfortable - and surprisingly very quiet for it's close to Bourbon Street location.
reviews.title: Location isn't everything!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed three nights in room 207, just at the top of the main stair. Can't understand the advice from HumbleHomo: 'stay away from 207'. It was a very pleasant experience for us, with no problems of noise, etc. Maybe it had been recently renovated - other rooms on that level were undergoing renovation. 207 perhaps is included in the 'one-bedroom suites' category, at lower price level - the bedroom is on a mezzanine level, over a comfortable sitting area with microwave and coffeemaker. The bedroom is dark, but has a good king-size bed. Bedroom ceiling height is restricted - could be a problem if you are 6'6"+. (See photo.) The bathroom is small but adequate and clean. The little balcony overlooking the courtyard is very nice, even if cluttered with a pile of bricks! There was no phone - 'oh yeh, the cord was cut during renovations and hasn't been replaced yet.'
reviews.title: A very pleasant experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Friendly, helpful staff. The place is a little quircky, but we really enjoyed our stay and have no complaints. Nice quiet cafe and bar just across the street, a couple of small delis nearby. Bourbon street also nearby but not intrusive. (But it is an awful place from early evening on - worth walking a bit further afield for nicer bars and restaurants.)
reviews.title: Perfect Pick in the Heart of the French Quarter

reviews.text: The Olivier House was built in 1838, if you want brand new this is not for you. This hotel is well maintainted and is the quintessential French Quarter hotel. It has 42 unquie rooms each one has it's own amenities and charm. We have stayed here three times and each time has been perfect! Our last trip was for our 15th anniversary. When I called to make the reservation I mentioned to them we would be celebrating our anniversary. We requested room 112, the same room we honeymooned in. After Mardi Gras the hotel began a extensive remodel of the room. When it become apparent to the staff the room would not be completed in time for our check in they had the contractors "pull" the room together for us. They worked on the room right up to when we checked in.I really appriecate that! They went to alot of trouble to honor my request. Their attention to custmer service sets them apart. We even had dive gear shipped to the hotel and picked it up when we arrived later. Now to address some of the other reviews: this hotel is located 1/2 block from Bourbon(need I say more?) I can imagane the street rooms can be noisey. Room 112 is located at the back of the courtyard so we have never had a problem with noise. Like I said each room is different and offers a different experience. As to ones safety as mentioned by Louise64London, I have never felt unsafe when walking (even by myself) in the blocks surrounding the hotel. When we where there last the mounted police used Toulouse as the resting place for their horses. We have stayed at other hotels in the French Quarter but this is our favorite. I have posted 10 pictures of room 112 I would have done more but thats the max.
reviews.title: Mixed

reviews.text: I had a very mixed experience staying here. On the positive side, I had a number of problems to do with my personal safety on the first night. The staff the next day were responsive and dealt with things without a fuss. They dealt with me very fairly. All credit. The staff generally were friendly and helpful. The atmosphere is delightful here. The rooms are very very mixed. Do not get the lobby room - it is not safe and noisy, and dark like a crypt. Other rooms are light and airy, however, things like an air conditioner for a different floor placed immediately outside my window made my room shudder from 7 am. This is just off Bourbon St which is either a great positive or a big down side - depending on your situation. Think carefully before staying in this area which is noisy with lots of gangs of young guys on frat / bachelor parties. The noise from nearby clubs goes for much of the night - great if you're in the club or want an easy stumble home! Great if you're with a gang who are here to party! Not so great if you're looking for something else. It's accessibility to the French Quarter is unbeatable, but there is much more to NO than the French Quarter. This place does attract the gangs of frat parties, and so think about whether you want that. The night staff did not manage security well. If you are a woman traveling alone, I would caution staying here (or anywhere in this neighborhood actually). I have really tried to be fair in this review. I think your experience here would depend very much on why you are visiting NO. I moved from this area to another district altogether and it suited me better. Would I stay here again? Jury is out. Not on my own.
reviews.title: Great charming Hotel close to the action

reviews.text: Great, charming hotel in the heart of the action right off Bourbon Street.
reviews.title: Little piece of heaven
Like on off-beat place, but this is too much
reviews.text: We checked into the Olivier House for our honeymoon...in what was called the honeymoon suite. It was an unusually cold weekend in NO.

reviews.title: The real New Orleans.
reviews.text: There was no heat at al in the room, the toilet didn't flush and the bathroom smelled like a porta-pot. We decided to make the best of things and turned on the fireplace which filled the hall and our room with gas. We had to move to another (SMALL!) attic room on the fourth floor where we were not able to take a shower-or use a toilet. They The major problem here is that nobody seemed even mildly apologetic that we had so many problems and this was our honeymoon. I would never stay here again and I do like a laid-back hotel with loads of personality, but this was just bad.

reviews.title: Funky & Fun
reviews.text: A great stay. Was inexpensive especially compared to other hotels I called. (the hotel next door was $200 more for a smaller room!) Staff are friendly and helpful. Would definitely stay again.

reviews.title: Don't Waste Your Money
reviews.text: Friendly, fun place to stay, nice people here. Close to everything. this is what the French Quarter is all about. We enjoyed our stay here. Go stay at the Marriott or similar hotel if you must, but if you came to enjoy New Orleans stay at a hotel like this one.

They were very welcoming and it was right in the heart of Bourbon St. We checked out early and they kept our car parked until we left town later in the day. This was my first trip to NO and I have stayed at nice new hotels but if you do that then you tend to miss out on hidden gems like this one. Will definitely be back
reviews.title: Old world charm

reviews.text: I stayed at the Olivier House the last week of October 2011 and really enjoyed it. I visited New Orleans about 15 years ago but stayed outside the French Quarter at a typical chain hotel. This time, I wanted to stay in the French Quarter, at a place that had the feel of the French Quarter. The Olivier House was a different, eclectic, enjoyable experience. When I walked in the front door, it felt more like walking into a large house back in the 19th Century. Every room is different. I stayed the first night in an interior room and although it really had no view, the room was well appointed, unique, had lots of exposed brick, quiet (and, yes, it had a flat screen TV....they must have upgraded) and I would have enjoyed staying in it the whole time. However, I had one of their suites for the rest of the trip. I enjoyed the large living room (which included a flat screen TV), the long wet bar running down the hall (which included a dorm size fridge) to the bedroom and the separate bedroom (with a second flat screen TV). I really enjoyed the small balcony overlooking Toulouse Street and could see the crowd on Bourbon Street less than a block away. When I got tired of the Bourbon Street partying and noise, I could close the French door to the balcony and it was then completely quiet. I enjoyed the Olivier House but went into it with a bit of an open mind and the expectation that it would be different and not like a 5 star chain hotel. It has the smallest elevator I have ever experienced, but it worked. No bar, no restaurant, nor room service but being just steps away from the bars and restaurants of Bourbon Street, this was not a problem. Also, the small neighborhood Toulouse House Grocery is just around the corner so you can pick up drinks and food for the in room fridge. I really liked the location. Never needed a car the whole trip. Everyday, I would just walk out the door and explore the French Quarter on foot, with no set destination. I hope to return.
reviews.title: Eclectic...with a good location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is an outstanding hotel located in the heart of the French Quarter, New Orleans. It is reasonably priced. The value is excellent compared to other hotels in the Quarter. It is centrally located for all your sightseeing trips in and around New Orleans. The hotel is situated just about one block from Bourbon Street, where all the "action" is and five blocks from Canal Street and the famed Street Car! However as you enter the hotel, you leave the hustle and bustle and noise from Bourbon Street behind and enter into another world reminiscent of the French colonial times! The furnishings are all period pieces. There is a large common sitting room next to the lobby and just behind that is a lush garden for relaxing and a Mint Julep. There is also a swimming pool for those hot humid summer days! The hotel is family run and the staff is excellent. They are friendly and will gladly help you with tours and suggestions if this is your first or tenth time in New Orleans. At the Olivier House you are within walking distance of everything the French Quarter has to offer you and as a bonus they have free parking in a secure lot just up the street, so if you are driving to New Orleans, as I did, you know that by staying at the Olivier House you not only have great accommodations, but a place to put your car at no extra charge. Olivier House Hotel is New Orleans.
reviews.title: Charming!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: New Orleans can be an edgy experience no matter where you stay: the city is a whiff of Paris, a pinch of Amsterdam and a belt from Fraternity Row. Knowing you are staying with family is invaluable when things go wrong. Now they did not go wrong for us, but we noticed at the Olivier House how gracious staff were to: the 20 something young lady who "over did" things and was fetched some Pepto Bismol, to the large Latino family looking for appropriate activities who received their information in perfect Spanish, and to endless numbers of people calling with a zillion questions about the city. Staff were as unfailingly patient and gracious as they were helpful and informed. Deborah was a study in quietly passionate devotion, even as she struggled through her own challenges. A young man on the night staff googled all the music of the moment in town for us. And owner's son Bobby responded immediately and fairly to a number of issues we had with our room, offering with no trace of irritation or judgement a reduced price on one night and our choice of what was available for the rest of the stay. We chose 112: its living room is a courtyard with a fountain and skylight. Opening French doors, you run smack dab into a huge elephant ear palm(?) in the large sitting room with couch, adjacent dining table, and kitchen/ bar. On the right is a black wrought iron circular staircase climbing to the loft bedroom. There are bathrooms on both levels. Shower for Adam, tub for Eve. Paradise found!
reviews.title: Personality, Passion and Poise

reviews.text: Normally I book my vacations via Orbitz, Expedia, Travelocity, etc... I was told about the Olivier House through a friend, and I couldn't be happier! It can sometimes be scary to take a chance on somewhere not known well, but I promise you will be satisfied!
reviews.title: Hidden Gem of New Orleans!

reviews.text: Hotel was filthy. Toilet didn't flush well. Velvet drapes hung to the floor and completely covered the window unit so we burned up at night. Tub didn't drain so showers were taken in 6" of standing water. No shampoo. Under bed, toilet, tub all filthy. Light in bathroom didn't have a switch; it had a cord that had to be plugged in. Does that even meet fire codes? Mattress was ancient and miserable. Bed had very loose post. No price is low enough for this place. It was recommended to me and I stayed against my intuition. Next time, I'll be at one of the many clean and comfortable guest houses or hotels in N.O. Quaint is not the same as nasty. This place is nasty.
reviews.title: Filthy. Broken down.
Great Experience!
reviews.text: Staying at the Olivier House was a great experience! We loved this charming old town house, it was actually my second time staying there, and I plan to go back again in October. If we needed anything, we just asked for it and they brought it to us. I found the staff to be extemely friendly and I loved hearing some of the old stories about the house. The court yard is beautiful and the decor in our room was cute. If you want generic, stay at one of the big hotels, if you want old world charm this is truly the place to stay. See you in October!

reviews.title: Olivier House big disappointment
reviews.text: Dingy, dirty, no services and lots of bugs. Don't stay here!

reviews.title: Neat Freaks would be happier elsewhere
reviews.text: The location and hospitality were top notch. But you can get the "authentic New Orleans experience" with a cleaner room and sturdier furniture. I have stayed at several hotels in the quarter and this is neither the best nor the worst. The architecture is beautiful and truely unique, like many of the old quarter hotels. If you go often, and love to see these old buildings, I would suggest you try it out. Otherwise, I'd look elsewhere.

reviews.title: Exactly what I expected NO to be
reviews.text: Alright, I read all these reviews and was very nervous to stay at the Olivier house, but decided to take the chance anyway. Loved it! Yes, New Orleans is BELOW sea level and is right on the water and is a very humid climate so WHY would you NOT expect a little mold? From some of the reviews I read, I imagined mold on the counters, mold in the pool, mold everywhere. I imagined toilets that were too disgusting to sit on etc. There was a little bit of mold in a crack here and there. duh. The bathrooms were very clean. The sheets and bedding was very clean. The carpets were a little musty from the climate and because there was no fan in the bathroom. The hotel is VERY charming and exactly what I expected my first trip to New Orleans to be. The staff were very polite and accomodating as well. Isn't the whole point of travelling to experience something new? If you want a homogenized experience, why leave home?

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed here two nights, on both ends of our trip to LA, two different rooms. The wallpaper was peeling but hey, they stapled it back on, cool! Very few lights in the rooms, tough to see at certain times of day. Tons of pillows on bed but would rather have some lights. The room at top of first flight of stairs was the more dissapointing of the two. The lobby was charming and whole building interestingly as most are in New Orleans but after getting home and checking prices again, we could have done better in equally interesting places. No, it's not four star as one supportive reviewer said but what's the excuse to not pull down the peeling wallpaper or have more than one lamp in a room? Our fourth trip to New Orleans and we thought we'd stay a new place but we won't stay there again. The staff was inconsistent, male staff was more helpful than the female staff, need to try a little harder. On the plus side, it was quiet enough and well located.
reviews.title: Lobby nice rooms not charming or well maintained

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This is not a four star hotel. This is authentic French Quarter. You can feel the history and almost see the ghosts. We will, without any doubt, be back. We had friends traveling with us who stayed across the street at a much more expensive hotel. They were very disappointed and spent most of their time in our awesome third floor room with a balcony. I loved the Olivier House!
reviews.title: Great New Orleans Experience

reviews.text: Woof! My name is Montana and I travel to all the best hotels with my mother. The Olivier House made my stay a 5 Paw experience they treated me like a princess which I am! Bobbie one of the owners made my first trip to Nawlins the best experience ever I'm a senior puppy and will never forget the great staff and how they fussed over me. All u pups out there bring ur owners to the Olivier house it's one of nawlins finest. See u guys next year
reviews.title: From a dog's perspective

reviews.text: My mother and I and our best friend come every year to NOLA. For the first time we stayed at the Olivier house.
reviews.title: Just like home

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: They could not have been nicer. It felt like we were home. Southern hospitality at its best !!!! Great Location. Just off bourbon. Peaceful.. Great price. Couldnt ask for more....
reviews.title: Love the Olivier House!
